member.name: T:Alis.Core.Audio.SFML.Listener
member.summary: The audio listener is the point in the scene from where all the sounds are heard

member.name: P:Alis.Core.Audio.SFML.Listener.GlobalVolume
member.summary: The volume is a number between 0 and 100; it is combined with the individual volume of each sound / music. The default value for the volume is 100 (maximum).

member.name: P:Alis.Core.Audio.SFML.Listener.Position
member.summary: 3D position of the listener (default is (0, 0, 0))

member.name: P:Alis.Core.Audio.SFML.Listener.Direction
member.summary: The direction (also called "at vector") is the vector pointing forward from the listener's perspective. Together with the up vector, it defines the 3D orientation of the listener in the scene. The direction vector doesn't have to be normalized. The default listener's direction is (0, 0, -1).

member.name: P:Alis.Core.Audio.SFML.Listener.UpVector
member.summary: The up vector is the vector that points upward from the listener's perspective. Together with the direction, it defines the 3D orientation of the listener in the scene. The up vector doesn't have to be normalized. The default listener's up vector is (0, 1, 0). It is usually not necessary to change it, especially in 2D scenarios.

member.summary: The my stream

member.summary: Constructs a music from an audio file
member.param: Path of the music file to open

member.summary: Constructs a music from a custom stream

member.name: M:Alis.Core.Audio.SFML.Music.#ctor(System.Byte[])
member.summary: Constructs a music from an audio file in memory
member.param: Byte array containing the file contents

member.name: P:Alis.Core.Audio.SFML.Music.SampleRate
member.summary: Sample rate of the music. The sample rate is the number of audio samples played per second. The higher, the better the quality.

member.name: P:Alis.Core.Audio.SFML.Music.ChannelCount
member.summary: Number of channels (1 = mono, 2 = stereo)

member.name: P:Alis.Core.Audio.SFML.Music.Status
member.summary: Current status of the music (see SoundStatus enum)

member.name: P:Alis.Core.Audio.SFML.Music.Duration
member.summary: Total duration of the music

member.name: P:Alis.Core.Audio.SFML.Music.Loop
member.summary: Flag if the music should loop after reaching the end. If set, the music will restart from beginning after reaching the end and so on, until it is stopped or Loop = false is set. The default looping state for music is false.

member.name: P:Alis.Core.Audio.SFML.Music.Pitch
member.summary: Pitch of the music. The pitch represents the perceived fundamental frequency of a sound; thus you can make a sound more acute or grave by changing its pitch. A side effect of changing the pitch is to modify the playing speed of the sound as well. The default value for the pitch is 1.

member.name: P:Alis.Core.Audio.SFML.Music.Volume
member.summary: Volume of the music. The volume is a value between 0 (mute) and 100 (full volume). The default value for the volume is 100.

member.name: P:Alis.Core.Audio.SFML.Music.Position
member.summary: 3D position of the music in the audio scene. Only sounds with one channel (mono sounds) can be spatialized. The default position of a sound is (0, 0, 0).

member.name: P:Alis.Core.Audio.SFML.Music.RelativeToListener
member.summary: Make the music's position relative to the listener or absolute. Making a sound relative to the listener will ensure that it will always be played the same way regardless the position of the listener. This can be useful for non-spatialized sounds, sounds that are produced by the listener, or sounds attached to it. The default value is false (position is absolute).

member.name: P:Alis.Core.Audio.SFML.Music.MinDistance
member.summary: Minimum distance of the music. The "minimum distance" of a sound is the maximum distance at which it is heard at its maximum volume. Further than the minimum distance, it will start to fade out according to its attenuation factor. A value of 0 ("inside the head of the listener") is an invalid value and is forbidden. The default value of the minimum distance is 1.

member.name: P:Alis.Core.Audio.SFML.Music.Attenuation
member.summary: Attenuation factor of the music. The attenuation is a multiplicative factor which makes the music more or less loud according to its distance from the listener. An attenuation of 0 will produce a non-attenuated sound, i.e. its volume will always be the same whether it is heard from near or from far. On the other hand, an attenuation value such as 100 will make the sound fade out very quickly as it gets further from the listener. The default value of the attenuation is 1.

member.name: P:Alis.Core.Audio.SFML.Music.PlayingOffset
member.summary: Current playing position of the music. The playing position can be changed when the music is either paused or playing.

member.name: P:Alis.Core.Audio.SFML.Music.LoopPoints
member.summary: Current loop points of the music. Since setting performs some adjustments on the provided values and rounds them to internal samples, getting this value later is not guaranteed to return the same times passed into it. However, it is guaranteed to return times that will map to the valid internal samples of this Music if they are later set again.

member.name: M:Alis.Core.Audio.SFML.Music.Play
member.summary: Start or resume playing the audio stream. This function starts the stream if it was stopped, resumes it if it was paused, and restarts it from beginning if it was it already playing. This function uses its own thread so that it doesn't block the rest of the program while the stream is played.

member.name: M:Alis.Core.Audio.SFML.Music.Pause
member.summary: Pause the audio stream. This function pauses the stream if it was playing, otherwise (stream already paused or stopped) it has no effect.

member.name: M:Alis.Core.Audio.SFML.Music.Stop
member.summary: Stop playing the audio stream. This function stops the stream if it was playing or paused, and does nothing if it was already stopped. It also resets the playing position (unlike Pause()).

member.name: P:Alis.Core.Audio.SFML.SoundRecorder.SampleRate
member.summary: Sample rate of the sound recorder.
member.remarks: The sample rate defines the number of audio samples captured per second. The higher, the better the quality (for example, 44100 samples/sec is CD quality).

member.name: P:Alis.Core.Audio.SFML.SoundRecorder.ChannelCount
member.summary: Get/Set the channel count of the audio capture device
member.remarks: This method allows you to specify the number of channels used for recording. Currently only 16-bit mono (1) and 16-bit stereo (2) are supported.

member.name: P:Alis.Core.Audio.SFML.SoundRecorder.IsAvailable
member.summary: Check if the system supports audio capture.
member.remarks: This function should always be called before using the audio capture features. If it returns false, then any attempt to use the SoundRecorder or one of its derived classes will fail.

member.name: P:Alis.Core.Audio.SFML.SoundRecorder.AvailableDevices
member.summary: Get the list of the names of all available audio capture devices

member.name: P:Alis.Core.Audio.SFML.SoundRecorder.DefaultDevice
member.summary: Get the name of the default audio capture device

member.name: M:Alis.Core.Audio.SFML.SoundRecorder.Start
member.summary: Start the capture using the default sample rate (44100 Hz). Please note that only one capture can happen at the same time.

member.name: M:Alis.Core.Audio.SFML.SoundRecorder.Start(System.UInt32)
member.summary: Start the capture. The sampleRate parameter defines the number of audio samples captured per second. The higher, the better the quality (for example, 44100 samples/sec is CD quality). This function uses its own thread so that it doesn't block the rest of the program while the capture runs. Please note that only one capture can happen at the same time.
member.param: Sound frequency; the more samples, the higher the quality (44100 by default = CD quality)

member.name: M:Alis.Core.Audio.SFML.SoundRecorder.Stop
member.summary: Stop the capture

member.name: M:Alis.Core.Audio.SFML.SoundRecorder.ToString
member.summary: Provide a string describing the object

member.name: M:Alis.Core.Audio.SFML.SoundRecorder.OnStart
member.summary: Start capturing audio data. This virtual function may be overridden by a derived class if something has to be done every time a new capture starts. If not, this function can be ignored; the default implementation does nothing.
member.returns: False to abort recording audio data, true to continue

member.name: M:Alis.Core.Audio.SFML.SoundRecorder.OnProcessSamples(System.Int16[])
member.summary: Process a new chunk of recorded samples. This virtual function is called every time a new chunk of recorded data is available. The derived class can then do whatever it wants with it (storing it, playing it, sending it over the network, etc.).
member.returns: False to stop recording audio data, true to continue

member.name: M:Alis.Core.Audio.SFML.SoundRecorder.OnStop
member.summary: Stop capturing audio data. This virtual function may be overridden by a derived class if something has to be done every time the capture ends. If not, this function can be ignored; the default implementation does nothing.

member.name: M:Alis.Core.Audio.SFML.SoundRecorder.SetProcessingInterval(Alis.Core.Audio.SFML.Time)
member.summary: The processing interval controls the period between calls to the onProcessSamples function. You may want to use a small interval if you want to process the recorded data in real time, for example. Note: this is only a hint, the actual period may vary. So don't rely on this parameter to implement precise timing. The default processing interval is 100 ms.

member.returns: True, if it was able to set the requested device

member.summary: Get the name of the current audio capture device
member.returns: The name of the current audio capture device

member.name: M:Alis.Core.Audio.SFML.SoundStream.#ctor
member.summary: Default constructor

member.name: P:Alis.Core.Audio.SFML.SoundStream.SampleRate
member.summary: Sample rate of the stream The sample rate is the number of audio samples played per second. The higher, the better the quality.

member.name: P:Alis.Core.Audio.SFML.SoundStream.ChannelCount
member.summary: Number of channels (1 = mono, 2 = stereo)

member.name: P:Alis.Core.Audio.SFML.SoundStream.Status
member.summary: Current status of the sound stream (see SoundStatus enum)

member.name: P:Alis.Core.Audio.SFML.SoundStream.Loop
member.summary: Flag if the music should loop after reaching the end. If set, the music will restart from beginning after reaching the end and so on, until it is stopped or Loop = false is set. The default looping state for music is false.

member.name: P:Alis.Core.Audio.SFML.SoundStream.Pitch
member.summary: Pitch of the stream. The pitch represents the perceived fundamental frequency of a sound; thus you can make a sound more acute or grave by changing its pitch. A side effect of changing the pitch is to modify the playing speed of the sound as well. The default value for the pitch is 1.

member.name: P:Alis.Core.Audio.SFML.SoundStream.Volume
member.summary: Volume of the stream. The volume is a value between 0 (mute) and 100 (full volume). The default value for the volume is 100.

member.name: P:Alis.Core.Audio.SFML.SoundStream.Position
member.summary: 3D position of the stream in the audio scene. Only sounds with one channel (mono sounds) can be spatialized. The default position of a sound is (0, 0, 0).

member.name: P:Alis.Core.Audio.SFML.SoundStream.RelativeToListener
member.summary: Make the stream's position relative to the listener or absolute. Making a sound relative to the listener will ensure that it will always be played the same way regardless the position of the listener. This can be useful for non-spatialized sounds, sounds that are produced by the listener, or sounds attached to it. The default value is false (position is absolute).

member.name: P:Alis.Core.Audio.SFML.SoundStream.MinDistance
member.summary: Minimum distance of the music. The "minimum distance" of a sound is the maximum distance at which it is heard at its maximum volume. Further than the minimum distance, it will start to fade out according to its attenuation factor. A value of 0 ("inside the head of the listener") is an invalid value and is forbidden. The default value of the minimum distance is 1.

member.name: P:Alis.Core.Audio.SFML.SoundStream.Attenuation
member.summary: Attenuation factor of the stream. The attenuation is a multiplicative factor which makes the music more or less loud according to its distance from the listener. An attenuation of 0 will produce a non-attenuated sound, i.e. its volume will always be the same whether it is heard from near or from far. On the other hand, an attenuation value such as 100 will make the sound fade out very quickly as it gets further from the listener. The default value of the attenuation is 1.

member.name: P:Alis.Core.Audio.SFML.SoundStream.PlayingOffset
member.summary: Current playing position of the stream. The playing position can be changed when the music is either paused or playing.

member.name: M:Alis.Core.Audio.SFML.SoundStream.Play
member.summary: Start or resume playing the audio stream. This function starts the stream if it was stopped, resumes it if it was paused, and restarts it from beginning if it was it already playing. This function uses its own thread so that it doesn't block the rest of the program while the stream is played.

member.name: M:Alis.Core.Audio.SFML.SoundStream.Pause
member.summary: Pause the audio stream. This function pauses the stream if it was playing, otherwise (stream already paused or stopped) it has no effect.

member.name: M:Alis.Core.Audio.SFML.SoundStream.Stop
member.summary: Stop playing the audio stream. This function stops the stream if it was playing or paused, and does nothing if it was already stopped. It also resets the playing position (unlike pause()).

member.name: M:Alis.Core.Graphic.SFML.Graphics.IRenderTarget.MapPixelToCoords(Alis.Core.Aspect.Math.Vector.Vector2I)
member.summary: Convert a point from target coordinates to world coordinates, using the current view This function is an overload of the MapPixelToCoords function that implicitly uses the current view. It is equivalent to: target.MapPixelToCoords(point, target.GetView());

member.name: M:Alis.Core.Graphic.SFML.Graphics.IRenderTarget.MapPixelToCoords(Alis.Core.Aspect.Math.Vector.Vector2I,Alis.Core.Graphic.SFML.Graphics.View)
member.summary: Convert a point from target coordinates to world coordinates This function finds the 2D position that matches the given pixel of the render-target. In other words, it does the inverse of what the graphics card does, to find the initial position of a rendered pixel. Initially, both coordinate systems (world units and target pixels) match perfectly. But if you define a custom view or resize your render-target, this assertion is not true anymore, ie. a point located at (10, 50) in your render-target may map to the point (150, 75) in your 2D world -- if the view is translated by (140, 25). For render-windows, this function is typically used to find which point (or object) is located below the mouse cursor. This version uses a custom view for calculations, see the other overload of the function if you want to use the current view of the render-target.
member.param: The view to use for converting the point

member.name: M:Alis.Core.Graphic.SFML.Graphics.IRenderTarget.MapCoordsToPixel(Alis.Core.Aspect.Math.Vector.Vector2)
member.summary: Convert a point from world coordinates to target coordinates, using the current view This function is an overload of the mapCoordsToPixel function that implicitly uses the current view. It is equivalent to: target.MapCoordsToPixel(point, target.GetView());
member.returns: The converted point, in target coordinates (pixels)

member.name: M:Alis.Core.Graphic.SFML.Graphics.IRenderTarget.MapCoordsToPixel(Alis.Core.Aspect.Math.Vector.Vector2,Alis.Core.Graphic.SFML.Graphics.View)
member.summary: Convert a point from world coordinates to target coordinates This function finds the pixel of the render-target that matches the given 2D point. In other words, it goes through the same process as the graphics card, to compute the final position of a rendered point. Initially, both coordinate systems (world units and target pixels) match perfectly. But if you define a custom view or resize your render-target, this assertion is not true anymore, ie. a point located at (150, 75) in your 2D world may map to the pixel (10, 50) of your render-target -- if the view is translated by (140, 25). This version uses a custom view for calculations, see the other overload of the function if you want to use the current view of the render-target.
member.param: The view to use for converting the point
member.returns: The converted point, in target coordinates (pixels)

member.name: M:Alis.Core.Graphic.SFML.Graphics.IRenderTarget.PushGlStates
member.summary: Save the current OpenGL render states and matrices. This function can be used when you mix SFML drawing and direct OpenGL rendering. Combined with PopGLStates, it ensures that: \li SFML's internal states are not messed up by your OpenGL code \li your OpenGL states are not modified by a call to a SFML function More specifically, it must be used around code that calls Draw functions. Example: // OpenGL code here... window.PushGLStates(); window.Draw(...); window.Draw(...); window.PopGLStates(); // OpenGL code here... Note that this function is quite expensive: it saves all the possible OpenGL states and matrices, even the ones you don't care about. Therefore it should be used wisely. It is provided for convenience, but the best results will be achieved if you handle OpenGL states yourself (because you know which states have really changed, and need to be saved and restored). Take a look at the ResetGLStates function if you do so.

member.name: M:Alis.Core.Graphic.SFML.Graphics.IRenderTarget.PopGlStates
member.summary: Restore the previously saved OpenGL render states and matrices. See the description of PushGLStates to get a detailed description of these functions.

member.name: M:Alis.Core.Graphic.SFML.Graphics.IRenderTarget.ResetGlStates
T:Alis.Core.Graphic.SFML.Graphics.PrimitiveType
member.summary: Types of primitives that a VertexArray can render. Points and lines have no area, therefore their thickness will always be 1 pixel, regardless the current transform and view.

members.member: List of individual points
List of individual lines
List of connected lines, a point uses the previous point to form a line
List of individual triangles
List of connected triangles, a point uses the two previous points to form a triangle
List of connected triangles, a point uses the common center and the previous point to form a triangle
List of individual quads
List of connected lines, a point uses the previous point to form a line
List of connected triangles, a point uses the two previous points to form a triangle
List of connected triangles, a point uses the common center and the previous point to form a triangle

member.name: M:Alis.Core.Graphic.SFML.Graphics.RenderTexture.MapPixelToCoords(Alis.Core.Aspect.Math.Vector.Vector2I)
member.summary: Convert a point from target coordinates to world coordinates, using the current view This function is an overload of the MapPixelToCoords function that implicitly uses the current view. It is equivalent to: target.MapPixelToCoords(point, target.GetView());

member.name: M:Alis.Core.Graphic.SFML.Graphics.RenderTexture.MapPixelToCoords(Alis.Core.Aspect.Math.Vector.Vector2I,Alis.Core.Graphic.SFML.Graphics.View)
member.summary: Convert a point from target coordinates to world coordinates This function finds the 2D position that matches the given pixel of the render-target. In other words, it does the inverse of what the graphics card does, to find the initial position of a rendered pixel. Initially, both coordinate systems (world units and target pixels) match perfectly. But if you define a custom view or resize your render-target, this assertion is not true anymore, ie. a point located at (10, 50) in your render-target may map to the point (150, 75) in your 2D world -- if the view is translated by (140, 25). For render-windows, this function is typically used to find which point (or object) is located below the mouse cursor. This version uses a custom view for calculations, see the other overload of the function if you want to use the current view of the render-target.
member.param: The view to use for converting the point

member.name: M:Alis.Core.Graphic.SFML.Graphics.RenderTexture.MapCoordsToPixel(Alis.Core.Aspect.Math.Vector.Vector2)
member.summary: Convert a point from world coordinates to target coordinates, using the current view This function is an overload of the mapCoordsToPixel function that implicitly uses the current view. It is equivalent to: target.MapCoordsToPixel(point, target.GetView());
member.returns: The converted point, in target coordinates (pixels)

member.name: M:Alis.Core.Graphic.SFML.Graphics.RenderTexture.MapCoordsToPixel(Alis.Core.Aspect.Math.Vector.Vector2,Alis.Core.Graphic.SFML.Graphics.View)
member.summary: Convert a point from world coordinates to target coordinates This function finds the pixel of the render-target that matches the given 2D point. In other words, it goes through the same process as the graphics card, to compute the final position of a rendered point. Initially, both coordinate systems (world units and target pixels) match perfectly. But if you define a custom view or resize your render-target, this assertion is not true anymore, ie. a point located at (150, 75) in your 2D world may map to the pixel (10, 50) of your render-target -- if the view is translated by (140, 25). This version uses a custom view for calculations, see the other overload of the function if you want to use the current view of the render-target.
member.param: The view to use for converting the point
member.returns: The converted point, in target coordinates (pixels)

member.name: M:Alis.Core.Graphic.SFML.Graphics.RenderTexture.PushGlStates
member.summary: Save the current OpenGL render states and matrices. This function can be used when you mix SFML drawing and direct OpenGL rendering. Combined with PopGLStates, it ensures that: \li SFML's internal states are not messed up by your OpenGL code \li your OpenGL states are not modified by a call to a SFML function More specifically, it must be used around code that calls Draw functions. Example: // OpenGL code here... window.PushGLStates(); window.Draw(...); window.Draw(...); window.PopGLStates(); // OpenGL code here... Note that this function is quite expensive: it saves all the possible OpenGL states and matrices, even the ones you don't care about. Therefore it should be used wisely. It is provided for convenience, but the best results will be achieved if you handle OpenGL states yourself (because you know which states have really changed, and need to be saved and restored). Take a look at the ResetGLStates function if you do so.

member.name: M:Alis.Core.Graphic.SFML.Graphics.RenderTexture.PopGlStates
member.summary: Restore the previously saved OpenGL render states and matrices. See the description of PushGLStates to get a detailed description of these functions.

member.name: M:Alis.Core.Graphic.SFML.Graphics.RenderTexture.ResetGlStates
M:Alis.Core.Graphic.SFML.Graphics.RenderTexture.SetActive(System.Boolean)
member.summary: Activate of deactivate the render texture as the current target for rendering
member.param: True to activate, false to deactivate (true by default)
member.returns: True if operation was successful, false otherwise

member.name: M:Alis.Core.Graphic.SFML.Graphics.RenderTexture.GenerateMipmap
member.summary: Generate a mipmap using the current texture data
member.remarks: This function is similar to and operates on the texture used as the target for drawing. Be aware that any draw operation may modify the base level image data. For this reason, calling this function only makes sense after all drawing is completed and display has been called. Not calling display after subsequent drawing will lead to undefined behavior if a mipmap had been previously generated.
member.returns: True if mipmap generation was successful, false if unsuccessful

member.name: M:Alis.Core.Graphic.SFML.Graphics.RenderWindow.PushGlStates
member.summary: Save the current OpenGL render states and matrices.

remarks.para: This function can be used when you mix SFML drawing and direct OpenGL rendering. Combined with PopGLStates, it ensures that:
SFML's internal states are not messed up by your OpenGL code
Your OpenGL states are not modified by a call to a SFML function
More specifically, it must be used around code that calls Draw functions.

Note that this function is quite expensive: it saves all the possible OpenGL states and matrices, even the ones you don't care about. Therefore it should be used wisely. It is provided for convenience, but the best results will be achieved if you handle OpenGL states yourself (because you know which states have really changed, and need to be saved and restored). Take a look at the function if you do so.

member.name: M:Alis.Core.Graphic.SFML.Graphics.RenderWindow.PopGlStates
member.summary: Restore the previously saved OpenGL render states and matrices. See the description of to get a detailed description of these functions.

member.name: M:Alis.Core.Graphic.SFML.Graphics.RenderWindow.ResetGlStates
member.summary: Reset the internal OpenGL states so that the target is ready for drawing.
member.remarks: This function can be used when you mix SFML drawing and direct OpenGL rendering, if you choose not to use PushGLStates/PopGLStates. It makes sure that all OpenGL states needed by SFML are set, so that subsequent Draw() calls will work as expected.

member.name: M:Alis.Core.Graphic.SFML.Graphics.Shader.#ctor(System.String,System.String,System.String)
member.summary: Load the vertex, geometry and fragment shaders from files
member.remarks: This function loads the vertex, geometry and fragment shaders. Pass NULL if you don't want to load a specific shader. The sources must be text files containing valid shaders in GLSL language. GLSL is a C-like language dedicated to OpenGL shaders; you'll probably need to read a good documentation for it before writing your own shaders.
member.param: Path of the vertex shader file to load, or null to skip this shader
Path of the geometry shader file to load, or null to skip this shader
Path of the fragment shader file to load, or null to skip this shader

member.name: M:Alis.Core.Graphic.SFML.Graphics.Shader.#ctor(System.IO.Stream,System.IO.Stream,System.IO.Stream)
member.summary: Load the vertex, geometry and fragment shaders from custom streams
member.remarks: This function loads the vertex, geometry and fragment shaders. Pass NULL if you don't want to load a specific shader. The sources must be valid shaders in GLSL language. GLSL is a C-like language dedicated to OpenGL shaders; you'll probably need to read a good documentation for it before writing your own shaders.
member.param: Source stream to read the vertex shader from, or null to skip this shader
Source stream to read the geometry shader from, or null to skip this shader
Source stream to read the fragment shader from, or null to skip this shader

member.summary: Construct the shader from a pointer

member.name: P:Alis.Core.Graphic.SFML.Graphics.Shader.NativeHandle
member.summary: Get the underlying OpenGL handle of the shader.
member.remarks: You shouldn't need to use this handle, unless you have very specific stuff to implement that SFML doesn't support.

member.name: P:Alis.Core.Graphic.SFML.Graphics.Shader.IsAvailable
member.summary: Tell whether or not the system supports shaders.
member.remarks: This property should always be checked before using the shader features. If it returns false, then any attempt to use Shader will fail.

member.name: P:Alis.Core.Graphic.SFML.Graphics.Shader.IsGeometryAvailable
member.summary: Tell whether or not the system supports geometry shaders.

remarks.para: This property should always be checked before using the geometry shader features. If it returns false, then any attempt to use geometry shader features will fail.
Note: The first call to this function, whether by your code or SFML will result in a context switch.

member.summary: Load the vertex, geometry and fragment shaders from source code in memory
member.remarks: This function loads the vertex, geometry and fragment shaders. Pass NULL if you don't want to load a specific shader. The sources must be valid shaders in GLSL language. GLSL is a C-like language dedicated to OpenGL shaders; you'll probably need to read a good documentation for it before writing your own shaders.
member.param: String containing the source code of the vertex shader
String containing the source code of the geometry shader
String containing the source code of the fragment shader

member.name: M:Alis.Core.Graphic.SFML.Graphics.Shader.SetUniform(System.String,Alis.Core.Graphic.SFML.Graphics.Texture)
member.summary: Specify a texture as sampler2D uniform

remarks.para: name is the name of the variable to change in the shader. The corresponding parameter in the shader must be a 2D texture (sampler2D GLSL type).

Example:
uniform sampler2D the_texture; // this is the variable in the shader
sf::Texture texture; ... shader.setUniform("the_texture", texture);
It is important to note that must remain alive as long as the shader uses it, no copy is made internally.

To use the texture of the object being drawn, which cannot be known in advance, you can pass the special value Shader.CurrentTexture:
shader.setUniform("the_texture", Shader.CurrentTexture);

member.param: Name of the texture in the shader

member.name: M:Alis.Core.Graphic.SFML.Graphics.Shader.SetUniform(System.String,Alis.Core.Graphic.SFML.Graphics.Shader.CurrentTextureType)
member.summary: Specify current texture as \p sampler2D uniform

remarks.para: This overload maps a shader texture variable to the texture of the object being drawn, which cannot be known in advance. The second argument must be . The corresponding parameter in the shader must be a 2D texture (sampler2D GLSL type).

member.param: Name of the texture in the shader

member.summary: Get the total number of points of the shape

member.name: M:Alis.Core.Graphic.SFML.Graphics.Shape.GetPoint(System.UInt32)
member.summary: Get the position of a point The returned point is in local coordinates, that is, the shape's transforms (position, rotation, scale) are not taken into account. The result is undefined if index is out of the valid range.
member.param: Index of the point to get, in range [0 .. PointCount - 1]

member.name: M:Alis.Core.Graphic.SFML.Graphics.Shape.GetLocalBounds
member.summary: Get the local bounding rectangle of the entity. The returned rectangle is in local coordinates, which means that it ignores the transformations (translation, rotation, scale, ...) that are applied to the entity. In other words, this function returns the bounds of the entity in the entity's coordinate system.
member.returns: Local bounding rectangle of the entity

member.name: M:Alis.Core.Graphic.SFML.Graphics.Shape.GetGlobalBounds
member.summary: Get the global bounding rectangle of the entity. The returned rectangle is in global coordinates, which means that it takes in account the transformations (translation, rotation, scale, ...) that are applied to the entity. In other words, this function returns the bounds of the sprite in the global 2D world's coordinate system.
member.returns: Global bounding rectangle of the entity

member.name: M:Alis.Core.Graphic.SFML.Graphics.Shape.Update
member.summary: Recompute the internal geometry of the shape. This function must be called by the derived class everytime the shape's points change (ie. the result of either PointCount or GetPoint is different).

member.summary: The my font

member.name: P:Alis.Core.Graphic.SFML.Graphics.Text.Color
member.summary: Fill color of the object
member.remarks: Deprecated. Use instead. By default, the text's fill color is opaque white. Setting the fill color to a transparent color with an outline will cause the outline to be displayed in the fill area of the text.

member.name: P:Alis.Core.Graphic.SFML.Graphics.Text.FillColor
member.summary: Fill color of the object
member.remarks: By default, the text's fill color is opaque white. Setting the fill color to a transparent color with an outline will cause the outline to be displayed in the fill area of the text.

member.name: P:Alis.Core.Graphic.SFML.Graphics.Text.OutlineColor
member.summary: Outline color of the object
member.remarks: By default, the text's outline color is opaque black.

member.name: P:Alis.Core.Graphic.SFML.Graphics.Text.OutlineThickness
member.summary: Thickness of the object's outline

remarks.para: By default, the outline thickness is 0.
Be aware that using a negative value for the outline thickness will cause distorted rendering.

member.name: P:Alis.Core.Graphic.SFML.Graphics.Texture.Srgb
member.summary: Enable or disable conversion from sRGB

remarks.para: When providing texture data from an image file or memory, it can either be stored in a linear color space or an sRGB color space. Most digital images account for gamma correction already, so they would need to be "uncorrected" back to linear color space before being processed by the hardware. The hardware can automatically convert it from the sRGB color space to a linear color space when it gets sampled. When the rendered image gets output to the final framebuffer, it gets converted back to sRGB.
After enabling or disabling sRGB conversion, make sure to reload the texture data in order for the setting to take effect.
This option is only useful in conjunction with an sRGB capable framebuffer. This can be requested during window creation.

member.name: M:Alis.Core.Graphic.SFML.Graphics.Texture.GenerateMipmap
member.summary: Generate a mipmap using the current texture data

remarks.para: Mipmaps are pre-computed chains of optimized textures. Each level of texture in a mipmap is generated by halving each of the previous level's dimensions. This is done until the final level has the size of 1x1. The textures generated in this process may make use of more advanced filters which might improve the visual quality of textures when they are applied to objects much smaller than they are. This is known as minification. Because fewer texels (texture elements) have to be sampled from when heavily minified, usage of mipmaps can also improve rendering performance in certain scenarios.

Mipmap generation relies on the necessary OpenGL extension being available. If it is unavailable or generation fails due to another reason, this function will return false. Mipmap data is only valid from the time it is generated until the next time the base level image is modified, at which point this function will have to be called again to regenerate it.

member.returns: True if mipmap generation was successful, false if unsuccessful

member.name: T:Alis.Core.Graphic.SFML.Graphics.Transformable
member.summary: Decomposed transform defined by a position, a rotation and a scale
member.remarks: A note on coordinates and undistorted rendering: By default, SFML (or more exactly, OpenGL) may interpolate drawable objects such as sprites or texts when rendering. While this allows transitions like slow movements or rotations to appear smoothly, it can lead to unwanted results in some cases, for example blurred or distorted objects. In order to render a SFML.Graphics.Drawable object pixel-perfectly, make sure the involved coordinates allow a 1:1 mapping of pixels in the window to texels (pixels in the texture). More specifically, this means: * The object's position, origin and scale have no fractional part * The object's and the view's rotation are a multiple of 90 degrees * The view's center and size have no fractional part

member.name: M:Alis.Core.Graphic.SFML.Graphics.VertexBuffer.Update(Alis.Core.Graphic.SFML.Graphics.Vertex[],System.UInt32,System.UInt32)
member.summary: Update a part of the buffer from an array of vertices offset is specified as the number of vertices to skip from the beginning of the buffer. If offset is 0 and vertexCount is equal to the size of the currently created buffer, its whole contents are replaced. If offset is 0 and vertexCount is greater than the size of the currently created buffer, a new buffer is created containing the vertex data. If offset is 0 and vertexCount is less than the size of the currently created buffer, only the corresponding region is updated. If offset is not 0 and offset + vertexCount is greater than the size of the currently created buffer, the update fails. No additional check is performed on the size of the vertex array, passing invalid arguments will lead to undefined behavior.
member.param: Array of vertices to copy to the buffer
Offset in the buffer to copy to

member.name: M:Alis.Core.Graphic.SFML.Graphics.VertexBuffer.Update(Alis.Core.Graphic.SFML.Graphics.Vertex[])
member.summary: Update a part of the buffer from an array of vertices assuming an offset of 0 and a vertex count the length of the passed array. If offset is 0 and vertexCount is equal to the size of the currently created buffer, its whole contents are replaced. If offset is 0 and vertexCount is greater than the size of the currently created buffer, a new buffer is created containing the vertex data. If offset is 0 and vertexCount is less than the size of the currently created buffer, only the corresponding region is updated. If offset is not 0 and offset + vertexCount is greater than the size of the currently created buffer, the update fails. No additional check is performed on the size of the vertex array, passing invalid arguments will lead to undefined behavior.
member.param: Array of vertices to copy to the buffer

member.name: M:Alis.Core.Graphic.SFML.Graphics.VertexBuffer.Update(Alis.Core.Graphic.SFML.Graphics.Vertex[],System.UInt32)
member.summary: Update a part of the buffer from an array of vertices assuming a vertex count the length of the passed array. If offset is 0 and vertexCount is equal to the size of the currently created buffer, its whole contents are replaced. If offset is 0 and vertexCount is greater than the size of the currently created buffer, a new buffer is created containing the vertex data. If offset is 0 and vertexCount is less than the size of the currently created buffer, only the corresponding region is updated. If offset is not 0 and offset + vertexCount is greater than the size of the currently created buffer, the update fails. No additional check is performed on the size of the vertex array, passing invalid arguments will lead to undefined behavior.
member.param: Array of vertices to copy to the buffer
Offset in the buffer to copy to

member.name: M:Alis.Core.Graphic.SFML.Windows.Cursor.#ctor(Alis.Core.Graphic.SFML.Windows.Cursor.CursorType)
member.summary: Create a native system cursor Refer to the list of cursor available on each system (see CursorType) to know whether a given cursor is expected to load successfully or is not supported by the operating system.

member.name: M:Alis.Core.Graphic.SFML.Windows.Cursor.#ctor(System.Byte[],Alis.Core.Aspect.Math.Vector.Vector2U,Alis.Core.Aspect.Math.Vector.Vector2U)
member.summary: Create a cursor with the provided image Pixels must be an array of width by height pixels in 32-bit RGBA format. If not, this will cause undefined behavior. If pixels is null or either width or height are 0, the current cursor is left unchanged and the function will return false. In addition to specifying the pixel data, you can also specify the location of the hotspot of the cursor. The hotspot is the pixel coordinate within the cursor image which will be located exactly where the mouse pointer position is. Any mouse actions that are performed will return the window/screen location of the hotspot. Warning: On Unix, the pixels are mapped into a monochrome bitmap: pixels with an alpha channel to 0 are transparent, black if the RGB channel are close to zero, and white otherwise.
member.param: Array of pixels of the image
Width and height of the image

member.summary: Give access to the real-time state of the joysticks

member.summary: Maximum number of supported joysticks

member.name: F:Alis.Core.Graphic.SFML.Windows.Joystick.ButtonCount
member.summary: Maximum number of supported buttons

member.summary: Maximum number of supported axes

member.name: M:Alis.Core.Graphic.SFML.Windows.Joystick.IsConnected(System.UInt32)
member.summary: Check if a joystick is connected
member.param: Index of the joystick to check
member.returns: True if the joystick is connected, false otherwise

members.member:
Return the number of buttons supported by a joystick
If the joystick is not connected, this function returns 0. Index of the joystick Number of buttons supported by the joystick

Check if a joystick supports a given axis
If the joystick is not connected, this function returns false. Index of the joystick Axis to check True if the joystick supports the axis, false otherwise

Check if a joystick button is pressed
If the joystick is not connected, this function returns false. Index of the joystick Button to check True if the button is pressed, false otherwise

Get the current position of a joystick axis
If the joystick is not connected, this function returns 0. Index of the joystick Axis to check Current position of the axis, in range [-100 .. 100]

Update the states of all joysticks
This function is used internally by SFML, so you normally don't have to call it explicitly. However, you may need to call it if you have no window yet (or no window at all): in this case the joysticks states are not updated automatically.

member.param: True to grab, false to release
member.remarks: If set, grabs the mouse cursor inside this window's client area so it may no longer be moved outside its bounds. Note that grabbing is only active while the window has focus and calling this function for fullscreen windows won't have any effect (fullscreen windows always grab the cursor).

member.summary: This buffer pool is instance thread safe Use GetBuffer to get a MemoryStream (with a publically accessible buffer) Calling Close on this MemoryStream will clear its internal buffer and return the buffer to the pool for reuse MemoryStreams can grow larger than the DEFAULT_BUFFER_SIZE (or whatever you passed in) and the underlying buffers will be returned to the pool at their larger sizes

member.name: P:Alis.Core.Network.WebSocketClientOptions.KeepAliveInterval
member.summary: How often to send ping requests to the Server This is done to prevent proxy servers from closing your connection The default is TimeSpan.Zero meaning that it is disabled. WebSocket servers usually send ping messages so it is not normally necessary for the client to send them (hence the TimeSpan.Zero default) You can manually control ping pong messages using the PingPongManager class. If you do that it is advisible to set this KeepAliveInterval to zero for the WebSocketClientFactory

member.name: P:Alis.Core.Network.WebSocketClientOptions.NoDelay
member.summary: Set to true to send a message immediately with the least amount of latency (typical usage for chat) This will disable Nagle's algorithm which can cause high tcp latency for small packets sent infrequently However, if you are streaming large packets or sending large numbers of small packets frequently it is advisable to set NoDelay to false This way data will be bundled into larger packets for better throughput

member.name: T:Alis.Core.Physic.Collision.Broadphase.DynamicTree`1
member.summary: A dynamic tree arranges data in a binary tree to accelerate queries such as volume queries and ray casts. Leafs are proxies with an AABB. In the tree we expand the proxy AABB by Settings.b2_fatAABBFactor so that the proxy AABB is bigger than the client object. This allows the client object to move by small amounts without triggering a tree update. Nodes are pooled and relocatable, so we use node indices rather than pointers.

member.name: M:Alis.Core.Physic.Collision.Broadphase.DynamicTree`1.Query(System.Func{System.Int32,System.Boolean},Alis.Core.Physic.Shared.Aabb@)
member.summary: Query an AABB for overlapping proxies. The callback class is called for each proxy that overlaps the supplied AABB.

member.name: M:Alis.Core.Physic.Collision.Broadphase.DynamicTree`1.RayCast(System.Func{Alis.Core.Physic.Collision.RayCast.RayCastInput,System.Int32,System.Single},Alis.Core.Physic.Collision.RayCast.RayCastInput@)
member.summary: Ray-cast against the proxies in the tree. This relies on the callback to perform a exact ray-cast in the case were the proxy contains a Shape. The callback also performs the any collision filtering. This has performance roughly equal to k * log(n), where k is the number of collisions and n is the number of proxies in the tree.
member.param: A callback class that is called for each proxy that is hit by the ray.
The ray-cast input data. The ray extends from p1 to p1 + maxFraction * (p2 - p1).

member.name: T:Alis.Core.Physic.Collision.Broadphase.DynamicTreeBroadPhase
member.summary: The broad-phase is used for computing pairs and performing volume queries and ray casts. This broad-phase does not persist pairs. Instead, this reports potentially new pairs. It is up to the client to consume the new pairs and to track subsequent overlap.

member.summary: Query an AABB for overlapping proxies. The callback class is called for each proxy that overlaps the supplied AABB.

member.name: M:Alis.Core.Physic.Collision.Broadphase.DynamicTreeBroadPhase.RayCast(System.Func{Alis.Core.Physic.Collision.RayCast.RayCastInput,System.Int32,System.Single},Alis.Core.Physic.Collision.RayCast.RayCastInput@)
member.summary: Ray-cast against the proxies in the tree. This relies on the callback to perform a exact ray-cast in the case were the proxy contains a shape. The callback also performs the any collision filtering. This has performance roughly equal to k * log(n), where k is the number of collisions and n is the number of proxies in the tree.
member.param: A callback class that is called for each proxy that is hit by the ray.
The ray-cast input data. The ray extends from p1 to p1 + maxFraction * (p2 - p1).

member.name: T:Alis.Core.Physic.Collision.Narrowphase.Manifold
member.summary: A manifold for two touching convex Shapes. Box2D supports multiple types of contact: - Clip point versus plane with radius - Point versus point with radius (circles) The local point usage depends on the manifold type: - ShapeType.Circles: the local center of circleA - SeparationFunction.FaceA: the center of faceA - SeparationFunction.FaceB: the center of faceB Similarly the local normal usage: - ShapeType.Circles: not used - SeparationFunction.FaceA: the normal on polygonA - SeparationFunction.FaceB: the normal on polygonB We store contacts in this way so that position correction can account for movement, which is critical for continuous physics. All contact scenarios must be expressed in one of these types. This structure is stored across time steps, so we keep it small.

member.summary: Not use for Type.SeparationFunction.Points

member.summary: Usage depends on manifold type

member.summary: The number of manifold points

member.summary: The type

member.name: T:Alis.Core.Physic.Collision.Narrowphase.ManifoldPoint
member.summary: A manifold point is a contact point belonging to a contact manifold. It holds details related to the geometry and dynamics of the contact points. The local point usage depends on the manifold type: -ShapeType.Circles: the local center of circleB -SeparationFunction.FaceA: the local center of cirlceB or the clip point of polygonB -SeparationFunction.FaceB: the clip point of polygonA This structure is stored across time steps, so we keep it small. Note: the impulses are used for internal caching and may not provide reliable contact forces, especially for high speed collisions.

member.name: F:Alis.Core.Physic.Collision.RayCast.RayCastInput.Fraction
member.summary: The ray extends from p1 to p1 + maxFraction * (p2 - p1). If you supply a max fraction of 1, the ray extends from p1 to p2. A max fraction of 0.5 makes the ray go from p1 and half way to p2.

member.name: T:Alis.Core.Physic.Collision.Shapes.ChainShape
member.summary: A chain shape is a free form sequence of line segments. The chain has one-sided collision, with the surface normal pointing to the right of the edge. This provides a counter-clockwise winding like the polygon shape. Connectivity information is used to create smooth collisions. Warning: the chain will not collide properly if there are self-intersections.

member.name: M:Alis.Core.Physic.Collision.TOI.TimeOfImpact.CalculateTimeOfImpact(Alis.Core.Physic.Collision.TOI.ToiInput@,Alis.Core.Physic.Collision.TOI.ToiOutput@)
member.summary: Compute the upper bound on time before two shapes penetrate. Time is represented as a fraction between [0,tMax]. This uses a swept separating axis and may miss some intermediate, non-tunneling collision. If you change the time interval, you should call this function again. Note: use Distance() to compute the contact point and normal at the time of impact.

member.name: T:Alis.Core.Physic.Config.Settings
member.summary: The settings class

member.name: F:Alis.Core.Physic.Config.Settings.ManifoldPoints
member.summary: The maximum number of contact points between two convex shapes. DO NOT CHANGE THIS VALUE!

member.name: F:Alis.Core.Physic.Config.Settings.EnableSubStepping
member.summary: Enable or disable sub stepping. Used for debugging.

member.name: F:Alis.Core.Physic.Config.Settings.BlockSolve
member.summary: Enable or disable the block contact solver. Used for debugging.

member.name: F:Alis.Core.Physic.Config.Settings.SkipSanityChecks
member.summary: Set this to true to skip sanity checks in the engine. This will speed up the tools by removing the overhead of the checks, but you will need to handle checks yourself where it is needed.

member.name: F:Alis.Core.Physic.Config.Settings.UseConvexHullPolygons
member.summary: If true, it will run a GiftWrap convex hull on all polygon inputs. This makes for a more stable engine when given random input, but if speed of the creation of polygons are more important, you might want to set this to false.

member.name: F:Alis.Core.Physic.Config.Settings.UseFpeCollisionCategories
member.summary: Velcro Physics has a different way of filtering fixtures than Box2d. We have both FPE and Box2D filtering in the engine. If you are upgrading from earlier versions of FPE, set this to true and DefaultFixtureCollisionCategories to Category.All.

member.name: F:Alis.Core.Physic.Config.Settings.DefaultFixtureCollisionCategories
member.summary: This is used by the Fixture constructor as the default value for Fixture.CollisionCategories member. Note that you may need to change this depending on the setting of UseFPECollisionCategories, above.

member.name: F:Alis.Core.Physic.Config.Settings.DefaultFixtureCollidesWith
member.summary: This is used by the Fixture constructor as the default value for Fixture.CollidesWith member.

member.name: F:Alis.Core.Physic.Config.Settings.DefaultFixtureIgnoreCcdWith
member.summary: This is used by the Fixture constructor as the default value for Fixture.IgnoreCCDWith member.

member.name: F:Alis.Core.Physic.Config.Settings.DefaultCollisionGroup
member.summary: Set the default collision group

member.name: F:Alis.Core.Physic.Config.Settings.GjkIterations
member.summary: Defines the maximum number of iterations made by the GJK algorithm.

member.name: F:Alis.Core.Physic.Config.Settings.AabbExtension
member.summary: This is used to fatten AABBs in the dynamic tree. This allows proxies to move by a small amount without triggering a tree adjustment. This is in meters.

member.name: F:Alis.Core.Physic.Config.Settings.AabbMultiplier
member.summary: This is used to fatten AABBs in the dynamic tree. This is used to predict the future position based on the current displacement. This is a dimensionless multiplier.

member.name: F:Alis.Core.Physic.Config.Settings.LinearSlop
member.summary: A small length used as a collision and constraint tolerance. Usually it is chosen to be numerically significant, but visually insignificant.

member.name: F:Alis.Core.Physic.Config.Settings.AngularSlop
member.summary: A small angle used as a collision and constraint tolerance. Usually it is chosen to be numerically significant, but visually insignificant.

member.name: F:Alis.Core.Physic.Config.Settings.SubSteps
member.summary: Maximum number of sub-steps per contact in continuous physics simulation.

member.name: F:Alis.Core.Physic.Config.Settings.ToiContacts
member.summary: Maximum number of contacts to be handled to solve a TOI impact.

member.name: F:Alis.Core.Physic.Config.Settings.LinearCorrection
member.summary: The maximum linear position correction used when solving constraints. This helps to prevent overshoot.

member.name: F:Alis.Core.Physic.Config.Settings.AngularCorrection
member.summary: The maximum angular position correction used when solving constraints. This helps to prevent overshoot.

member.name: F:Alis.Core.Physic.Config.Settings.Translation
member.summary: The maximum linear velocity of a body. This limit is very large and is used to prevent numerical problems. You shouldn't need to adjust this.

member.name: F:Alis.Core.Physic.Config.Settings.Rotation
member.summary: The maximum angular velocity of a body. This limit is very large and is used to prevent numerical problems. You shouldn't need to adjust this.

member.name: F:Alis.Core.Physic.Config.Settings.Baumgarte
member.summary: This scale factor controls how fast overlap is resolved. Ideally this would be 1 so that overlap is removed in one time step. However using values close to 1 often lead to overshoot.

member.name: F:Alis.Core.Physic.Config.Settings.ToiBaumgarte
member.summary: The toi baumgarte

member.name: F:Alis.Core.Physic.Config.Settings.TimeToSleep
member.summary: The time that a body must be still before it will go to sleep.

member.name: F:Alis.Core.Physic.Config.Settings.LinearSleepTolerance
member.summary: A body cannot sleep if its linear velocity is above this tolerance.

member.name: F:Alis.Core.Physic.Config.Settings.AngularSleepTolerance
member.summary: A body cannot sleep if its angular velocity is above this tolerance.

member.name: F:Alis.Core.Physic.Config.Settings.AutoClearForces
member.summary: By default, forces are cleared automatically after each call to Step. The default behavior is modified with this setting. The purpose of this setting is to support sub-stepping. Sub-stepping is often used to maintain a fixed sized time step under a variable frame-rate. When you perform sub-stepping you should disable auto clearing of forces and instead call ClearForces after all sub-steps are complete in one pass of your game loop.

member.name: F:Alis.Core.Physic.Config.Settings.PolygonVertices
member.summary: The maximum number of vertices on a convex polygon.

member.name: F:Alis.Core.Physic.Config.Settings.PolygonRadius
member.summary: The radius of the polygon/edge shape skin. This should not be modified. Making this smaller means polygons will have an insufficient buffer for continuous collision. Making it larger may create artifacts for vertex collision.

member.name: F:Alis.Core.Physic.Config.Settings.MixFriction
member.summary: Gets called when there is a collision between 2 fixtures. The first two parameters are the friction values of either fixture. The return value should be the desired friction value of the collection.

member.name: F:Alis.Core.Physic.Config.Settings.MixRestitution
member.summary: Gets called when there is a collision between 2 fixtures. The first two parameters are the restitution values of either fixture. The return value should be the desired restitution value of the collection.

member.name: F:Alis.Core.Physic.Config.Settings.MixRestitutionThreshold
member.summary: The default mix restitution threshold

member.name: M:Alis.Core.Physic.Config.Settings.DefaultMixFriction(System.Single,System.Single)
member.summary: Friction mixing law. The idea is to allow either fixture to drive the friction to zero. For example, anything slides on ice.

member.name: M:Alis.Core.Physic.Config.Settings.DefaultMixRestitution(System.Single,System.Single)
member.summary: Restitution mixing law. The idea is allow for anything to bounce off an inelastic surface. For example, a superball bounces on anything.

member.name: M:Alis.Core.Physic.Config.Settings.DefaultMixRestitutionThreshold(System.Single,System.Single)
member.summary: Restitution mixing law. This picks the lowest value.

member.name: P:Alis.Core.Physic.Dynamics.Body.IsBullet
member.summary: Gets or sets a value indicating whether this body should be included in the CCD solver.
member.value: true if this instance is included in CCD; otherwise, false.

member.name: P:Alis.Core.Physic.Dynamics.Body.SleepingAllowed
member.summary: You can disable sleeping on this body. If you disable sleeping, the body will be woken.
member.value: true if sleeping is allowed; otherwise, false.

member.name: P:Alis.Core.Physic.Dynamics.Body.Awake
member.summary: Set the sleep state of the body. A sleeping body has very low CPU cost.

member.name: P:Alis.Core.Physic.Dynamics.Body.Enabled
member.summary: Set the active state of the body. An inactive body is not simulated and cannot be collided with or woken up. If you pass a flag of true, all fixtures will be added to the broad-phase. If you pass a flag of false, all fixtures will be removed from the broad-phase and all contacts will be destroyed. Fixtures and joints are otherwise unaffected. You may continue to create/destroy fixtures and joints on inactive bodies. Fixtures on an inactive body are implicitly inactive and will not participate in collisions, ray-casts, or queries. Joints connected to an inactive body are implicitly inactive. An inactive body is still owned by a b2World object and remains in the body list.

member.name: P:Alis.Core.Physic.Dynamics.Body.FixedRotation
member.summary: Set this body to have fixed rotation. This causes the mass to be reset.
member.value: true if it has fixed rotation; otherwise, false.

member.summary: Body objects can define which categories of bodies they wish to ignore CCD with. This allows certain bodies to be configured to ignore CCD with objects that aren't a penetration problem due to the way content has been prepared. This is compared against the other Body's fixture CollisionCategories within World.SolveTOI().

member.name: M:Alis.Core.Physic.Dynamics.Body.AddFixture(Alis.Core.Physic.Dynamics.Fixture)
member.summary: Creates a fixture and attach it to this body. If the density is non-zero, this function automatically updates the mass of the body. Contacts are not created until the next time step. Warning: This function is locked during callbacks.

member.name: M:Alis.Core.Physic.Dynamics.Body.AddFixture(Alis.Core.Physic.Collision.Shapes.Shape)
member.summary: Creates a fixture and attach it to this body. If the density is non-zero, this function automatically updates the mass of the body. Contacts are not created until the next time step. Warning: This function is locked during callbacks.

member.name: M:Alis.Core.Physic.Dynamics.Body.RemoveFixture(Alis.Core.Physic.Dynamics.Fixture)
member.summary: Destroy a fixture. This removes the fixture from the broad-phase and destroys all contacts associated with this fixture. This will automatically adjust the mass of the body if the body is dynamic and the fixture has positive density. All fixtures attached to a body are implicitly destroyed when the body is destroyed. Warning: This function is locked during callbacks.

member.summary: Applies a force at the center of mass.

The world position of the point of application.

member.summary: A fixture is used to attach a Shape to a body for collision detection. A fixture inherits its transform from its parent. Fixtures hold additional non-geometric data such as friction, collision filters, etc. Fixtures are created via Body.CreateFixture. Warning: You cannot reuse fixtures.

member.name: F:Alis.Core.Physic.Dynamics.Fixture.AfterCollision
member.summary: Fires after two shapes has collided and are solved. This gives you a chance to get the impact force.

member.name: F:Alis.Core.Physic.Dynamics.Fixture.BeforeCollision
member.summary: Fires when two fixtures are close to each other. Due to how the broadphase works, this can be quite inaccurate as shapes are approximated using AABBs.

member.name: F:Alis.Core.Physic.Dynamics.Fixture.CollidesWithprivate
member.summary: The collides with

member.name: F:Alis.Core.Physic.Dynamics.Fixture.CollisionCategoriesprivate
member.summary: The collision categories

member.name: F:Alis.Core.Physic.Dynamics.Fixture.CollisionGroupPrivate
member.summary: The collision group

member.name: F:Alis.Core.Physic.Dynamics.Fixture.IsSensorPrivate
member.summary: The is sensor

member.name: F:Alis.Core.Physic.Dynamics.Fixture.OnCollision
member.summary: Fires when two shapes collide and a contact is created between them. Note that the first fixture argument is always the fixture that the delegate is subscribed to.

member.name: F:Alis.Core.Physic.Dynamics.Fixture.OnSeparation
member.summary: Fires when two shapes separate and a contact is removed between them. Note: This can in some cases be called multiple times, as a fixture can have multiple contacts. Note The first fixture argument is always the fixture that the delegate is subscribed to.

member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class

member.summary: Contact filtering data.

member.summary: Gets or sets the value of the ignore ccd with

member.summary: Gets the value of the proxies

member.name: P:Alis.Core.Physic.Dynamics.Fixture.ProxyCount
member.summary: Gets the value of the proxy count

member.name: P:Alis.Core.Physic.Dynamics.Fixture.RestitutionThreshold
member.summary: Get or set the restitution threshold. This will _not_ change the restitution threshold of existing contacts.

member.name: P:Alis.Core.Physic.Dynamics.Fixture.CollisionGroup
member.summary: Defaults to 0 If Settings.UseFPECollisionCategories is set to false: Collision groups allow a certain group of objects to never collide (negative) or always collide (positive). Zero means no collision group. Non-zero group filtering always wins against the mask bits. If Settings.UseFPECollisionCategories is set to true: If 2 fixtures are in the same collision group, they will not collide.

member.name: P:Alis.Core.Physic.Dynamics.Fixture.CollidesWith
member.summary: Defaults to Category.All The collision mask bits. This states the categories that this fixture would accept for collision. Use Settings.UseFPECollisionCategories to change the behavior.

member.name: P:Alis.Core.Physic.Dynamics.Fixture.CollisionCategories
member.summary: The collision categories this fixture is a part of. If Settings.UseFPECollisionCategories is set to false: Defaults to Category.Cat1 If Settings.UseFPECollisionCategories is set to true: Defaults to Category.All

member.name: P:Alis.Core.Physic.Dynamics.Fixture.Shape
member.summary: Get the child Shape. You can modify the child Shape, however you should not change the number of vertices because this will crash some collision caching mechanisms.

member.name: P:Alis.Core.Physic.Dynamics.Fixture.IsSensor
member.summary: Gets or sets a value indicating whether this fixture is a sensor.
member.value: true if this instance is a sensor; otherwise, false.

member.name: P:Alis.Core.Physic.Dynamics.Fixture.Body
member.summary: Get the parent body of this fixture. This is null if the fixture is not attached.

member.name: P:Alis.Core.Physic.Dynamics.Fixture.Friction
member.summary: Set the coefficient of friction. This will _not_ change the friction of existing contacts.

member.name: P:Alis.Core.Physic.Dynamics.Fixture.Restitution
member.summary: Set the coefficient of restitution. This will not change the restitution of existing contacts.

member.name: M:Alis.Core.Physic.Dynamics.Fixture.Refilter
member.summary: Contacts are persistent and will keep being persistent unless they are flagged for filtering. This methods flags all contacts associated with the body for filtering.

member.summary: This requires defining an anchor point on both bodies and the non-zero length of the distance joint. If you don't supply a length, the local anchor points is used so that the initial configuration can violate the constraint slightly. This helps when saving and loading a game. Warning Do not use a zero or short length.

member.name: T:Alis.Core.Physic.Dynamics.Joints.FixedMouseJoint
member.summary: A mouse joint is used to make a point on a body track a specified world point. This a soft constraint with a maximum force. This allows the constraint to stretch and without applying huge forces. NOTE: this joint is not documented in the manual because it was developed to be used in the testbed. If you want to learn how to use the mouse joint, look at the testbed.

member.name: T:Alis.Core.Physic.Dynamics.Joints.GearJoint
member.summary: A gear joint is used to connect two joints together. Either joint can be a revolute or prismatic joint. You specify a gear ratio to bind the motions together: coordinate1 + ratio * coordinate2 = ant The ratio can be negative or positive. If one joint is a revolute joint and the other joint is a prismatic joint, then the ratio will have units of length or units of 1/length. Warning: You have to manually destroy the gear joint if jointA or jointB is destroyed.

member.summary: This requires defining a line of motion using an axis and an anchor point. The definition uses local anchor points and a local axis so that the initial configuration can violate the constraint slightly. The joint translation is zero when the local anchor points coincide in world space. Using local anchors and a local axis helps when saving and loading a game.
member.param: Set to true if you are using world coordinates as anchors.

member.name: T:Alis.Core.Physic.Dynamics.Joints.PulleyJoint
member.summary: The pulley joint is connected to two bodies and two fixed world points. The pulley supports a ratio such that: length1 + ratio * length2 <= constant Yes, the force transmitted is scaled by the ratio. Warning: the pulley joint can get a bit squirrelly by itself. They often work better when combined with prismatic joints. You should also cover the the anchor points with static shapes to prevent one side from going to zero length.

member.name: T:Alis.Core.Physic.Dynamics.Joints.RevoluteJoint
member.summary: A revolute joint constrains to bodies to share a common point while they are free to rotate about the point. The relative rotation about the shared point is the joint angle. You can limit the relative rotation with a joint limit that specifies a lower and upper angle. You can use a motor to drive the relative rotation about the shared point. A maximum motor torque is provided so that infinite forces are not generated.

member.name: T:Alis.Core.Physic.Dynamics.Joints.WeldJoint
member.summary: A weld joint essentially glues two bodies together. A weld joint may distort somewhat because the island constraint solver is approximate. The joint is soft constraint based, which means the two bodies will move relative to each other, when a force is applied. To combine two bodies in a rigid fashion, combine the fixtures to a single body instead.

member.summary: The frequency of the joint. A higher frequency means a stiffer joint, but a too high value can cause the joint to oscillate. Default is 0, which means the joint does no spring calculations.

member.name: P:Alis.Core.Physic.Dynamics.Joints.WeldJoint.Damping
member.summary: The damping on the joint. The damping is only used when the joint has a frequency (> 0). A higher value means more damping.

member.name: T:Alis.Core.Physic.Dynamics.Joints.WheelJoint
member.summary: A wheel joint. This joint provides two degrees of freedom: translation along an axis fixed in bodyA and rotation in the plane. In other words, it is a point to line constraint with a rotational motor and a linear spring/damper. The spring/damper is initialized upon creation. This joint is designed for vehicle suspensions.

member.summary: Defines how the value is determined for position before first point or after the end point on the .

member.name: F:Alis.Core.Physic.Extensions.Controllers.Wind.Curve.CurveLoopType.Constant
member.summary: The value of will be evaluated as first point for positions before the beginning and end point for positions after the end.

member.name: F:Alis.Core.Physic.Extensions.Controllers.Wind.Curve.CurveLoopType.Cycle
member.summary: The positions will wrap around from the end to beginning of the for determined the value.

member.name: F:Alis.Core.Physic.Extensions.Controllers.Wind.Curve.CurveLoopType.CycleOffset
member.summary: The positions will wrap around from the end to beginning of the . The value will be offset by the difference between the values of first and end multiplied by the wrap amount. If the position is before the beginning of the the difference will be subtracted from its value; otherwise the difference will be added.

member.name: F:Alis.Core.Physic.Extensions.Controllers.Wind.Curve.CurveLoopType.Oscillate
member.summary: The value at the end of the act as an offset from the same side of the toward the opposite side.

member.name: F:Alis.Core.Physic.Extensions.Controllers.Wind.Curve.CurveLoopType.Linear
member.summary: The linear interpolation will be performed for determined the value.

member.summary: Defines the different tangent types to be calculated for points in a .

member.summary: The tangent which always has a value equal to zero.

member.name: F:Alis.Core.Physic.Extensions.Controllers.Wind.Curve.CurveTangent.Linear
member.summary: The tangent which contains a difference between current tangent value and the tangent value from the previous .

member.name: F:Alis.Core.Physic.Extensions.Controllers.Wind.Curve.CurveTangent.Smooth
member.summary: The smoouth tangent which contains the inflection between and by taking into account the values of both neighbors of the .

member.returns: true if it is convex; otherwise, false.

member.summary: Checks if the vertices forms an simple polygon by checking for edge crossings.

member.name: M:Alis.Core.Physic.Shared.Vertices.CheckPolygon
member.summary: Checks if the polygon is valid for use in the engine. Performs a full check, for simplicity, convexity, orientation, minimum angle, and volume. From Eric Jordan's convex decomposition library
member.returns: PolygonError.NoError if there were no error.

member.name: M:Alis.Core.Physic.Shared.Vertices.ProjectToAxis(Alis.Core.Aspect.Math.Vector.Vector2@,System.Single@,System.Single@)
member.summary: Projects to axis.

members.member:
Winding number test for a point in a polygon. See more info about the algorithm here: http://softsurfer.com/Archive/algorithm_0103/algorithm_0103.htm The point to be tested.
-1 if the winding number is zero and the point is outside the polygon, 1 if the point is inside the polygon, and 0 if the point is on the polygons edge.

member.name: M:Alis.Core.Physic.Shared.Vertices.PointInPolygonAngle(Alis.Core.Aspect.Math.Vector.Vector2@)
member.summary: Compute the sum of the angles made between the test point and each pair of points making up the polygon. If this sum is 2pi then the point is an interior point, if 0 then the point is an exterior point. ref: http://ozviz.wasp.uwa.edu.au/~pbourke/geometry/insidepoly/ - Solution 2

member.name: T:Alis.Core.Physic.Tools.ConvexHull.Melkman
member.summary: Creates a convex hull. Note: 1. Vertices must be of a simple polygon, i.e. edges do not overlap. 2. Melkman does not work on point clouds
member.remarks: Implemented using Melkman's Convex Hull Algorithm - O(n) time complexity. Reference: http://www.ams.sunysb.edu/~jsbm/courses/345/melkman.pdf

member.name: M:Alis.Core.Physic.Tools.Cutting.YuPengClipper.Execute(Alis.Core.Physic.Shared.Vertices,Alis.Core.Physic.Shared.Vertices,Alis.Core.Physic.Tools.Cutting.Simple.PolyClipType,Alis.Core.Physic.Tools.Cutting.Simple.PolyClipError@)
member.summary: Implements "A new algorithm for Boolean operations on general polygons" available here: http://liama.ia.ac.cn/wiki/_media/user:dong:dong_cg_05.pdf Merges two polygons, a subject and a clip with the specified operation. Polygons may not be self-intersecting. Warning: May yield incorrect results or even crash if polygons contain collinear points.
member.param: The clip polygon, which is added, substracted or intersected with the subject
The operation to be performed. Either Union, Difference or Intersection.

member.summary: Convex decomposition algorithm created by Mark Bayazit (http://mnbayazit.com/) Properties: - Tries to decompose using polygons instead of triangles. - Tends to produce optimal results with low processing time. - Running time is O(nr), n = number of vertices, r = reflex vertices. - Does not support holes. For more information about this algorithm, see http://mnbayazit.com/406/bayazit

member.name: T:Alis.Core.Physic.Tools.Triangulation.Delaunay.CdtDecomposer
member.summary: 2D constrained Delaunay triangulation algorithm. Based on the paper "Sweep-line algorithm for constrained Delaunay triangulation" by V. Domiter and and B. Zalik Properties: - Creates triangles with a large interior angle. - Supports holes - Generate a lot of garbage due to incapsulation of the Poly2Tri library. - Running time is O(n^2), n = number of vertices. - Does not care about winding order. Source: http://code.google.com/p/poly2tri/

member.summary: When we need to traverse from one triangle to the next we need the point in current triangle that is the opposite point to the next triangle.
After a flip we have two triangles and know that only one will still be intersecting the edge. So decide which to contiune with and legalize the other
member.param: should be the result of an TriangulationUtil.orient2d( eq, op, ep )
a point shared by both triangles
another point shared by both triangles
member.returns: returns the triangle still intersecting the edge

member.summary: Scan part of the FlipScan algorithm When a triangle pair isn't flippable we will scan for the next point that is inside the flip triangle scan area. When found we generate a new flipEdgeEvent
member.param: last point on the edge we are traversing
first point on the edge we are traversing
the current triangle sharing the point eq with edge

member.name: F:Alis.Core.Physic.Tools.Triangulation.Delaunay.TriangulationUtil.Epsilon
member.summary: The epsilon

Requirements: 1. a,b and c form a triangle. 2. a and d is know to be on opposite side of bc
a + / \ / \ b/ \c +-------+ / B \ / \
Facts: d has to be in area B to have a chance to be inside the circle formed by a,b and c d is outside B if orient2d(a,b,d) or orient2d(c,a,d) is CW This preknowledge gives us a way to optimize the incircle test
member.returns: true if d is inside circle, false if on circle edge

member.summary: Describes whether in scan area

members.member: Forumla to calculate signed area Positive if CCW Negative if CW 0 if collinear A[P1,P2,P3] = (x1*y2 - y1*x2) + (x2*y3 - y2*x3) + (x3*y1 - y3*x1) = (x1-x3)*(y2-y3) - (y1-y3)*(x2-x3)

member.name: T:Alis.Core.Physic.Tools.Triangulation.Earclip.EarclipDecomposer
member.summary: Convex decomposition algorithm using ear clipping Properties: - Only works on simple polygons. - Does not support holes. - Running time is O(n^2), n = number of vertices. Source: http://www.ewjordan.com/earClip/

member.name: M:Alis.Core.Physic.Tools.Triangulation.Earclip.EarclipDecomposer.ConvexPartition(Alis.Core.Physic.Shared.Vertices,System.Single)
member.summary: Decompose the polygon into several smaller non-concave polygon. Each resulting polygon will have no more than Settings.MaxPolygonVertices vertices.

member.name: M:Alis.Core.Physic.Tools.Triangulation.Earclip.EarclipDecomposer.TriangulatePolygon(Alis.Core.Physic.Shared.Vertices,System.Single)
member.summary: Triangulates a polygon using simple ear-clipping algorithm. Returns size of Triangle array unless the polygon can't be triangulated. This should only happen if the polygon self-intersects, though it will not _always_ return null for a bad polygon - it is the caller's responsibility to check for self-intersection, and if it doesn't, it should at least check that the return value is non-null before using. You're warned! Triangles may be degenerate, especially if you have identical points in the input to the algorithm. Check this before you use them. This is totally unoptimized, so for large polygons it should not be part of the simulation loop.
member.remarks: Only works on simple polygons.

member.name: M:Alis.Core.Physic.Tools.Triangulation.Earclip.EarclipDecomposer.ResolvePinchPoint(Alis.Core.Physic.Shared.Vertices,Alis.Core.Physic.Shared.Vertices@,Alis.Core.Physic.Shared.Vertices@,System.Single)
member.summary: Finds and fixes "pinch points," points where two polygon vertices are at the same point. If a pinch point is found, pin is broken up into poutA and poutB and true is returned; otherwise, returns false. Mostly for internal use. O(N^2) time, which sucks...

member.name: T:Alis.Core.Physic.Tools.Triangulation.Seidel.SeidelDecomposer
member.summary: Convex decomposition algorithm created by Raimund Seidel Properties: - Decompose the polygon into trapezoids, then triangulate. - To use the trapezoid data, use ConvexPartitionTrapezoid() - Generate a lot of garbage due to incapsulation of the Poly2Tri library. - Running time is O(n log n), n = number of vertices. - Running time is almost linear for most simple polygons. - Does not care about winding order. For more information, see Raimund Seidel's paper "A simple and fast incremental randomized algorithm for computing trapezoidal decompositions and for triangulating polygons" See also: "Computational Geometry", 3rd edition, by Mark de Berg et al, Chapter 6.2 "Computational Geometry in C", 2nd edition, by Joseph O'Rourke Original code from the Poly2Tri project by Mason Green. http://code.google.com/p/poly2tri/source/browse?repo=archive#hg/scala/src/org/poly2tri/seidel This implementation is from Dec 14, 2010

member.param: The sheer to use if you get bad results, try using a higher value.
